column3:

column1: December Darkness Across the Universe (Discover Magazine)
column3:
During the darkest days of December, it makes me feel better to think about
all the other, more profound darknesses out there in the universe. A little
dose of the old perspective, you know. And boy, there are a lot of them--not
just a lot of dark places, but a lot of different forms of darkness out there.
In fact, there's a lot more darkness than most of us realize, for an obvious
if easily overlooked reason: Space images are calibrated to highlight faint or

column1: Device created to save crops, raise farm incomes in developing world (Eurekalert)
column3:
(_Terry Collins Assoc_) CGIAR's research institute in India, ICRISAT,
introduces a $300 combination mobile phone/tablet computer specifically
designed for developing world farm conditions and to improve the crop success
and incomes of smallholder farmers.The device provides information in local
dialects geared to individual farms: eg. lowest available farm input prices
and real time market prices for produce, best practices to maximize crop
yields given local soils and climate, and threats of damage from incoming
weather or pests.

column1: First scientific report shows police body-cameras can prevent unacceptable use-of-force (Eurekalert)
column3:
As Obama pledges investment in body-worn-camera technology for police
officers, researchers say cameras induce 'self-awareness' that can prevent
unacceptable uses-of-force seen to have tragic consequences in the US over the
past year -- from New York to Ferguson -- but warn that cameras have
implications for prosecution and data storage.

column1: NASA looks at some severe holiday weather from space (Eurekalert)
column3:
(_NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center_) Severe weather in the form of tornadoes
is not something people expect on Christmas week but a storm system on Dec. 23
brought tornadoes to Mississippi, Georgia and Louisiana. As the storm moved,
NASA's RapidScat captured data on winds while NOAA's GOES satellite tracked
the movement of the system.

column1: Water Source for Almonds in California May Run Dry (New York Times)
column3:
The business of growing almonds has thrived in California despite drought
because of a federally controlled project that allowed for Sacramento River
water flows, but the law requires that that source nurture salmon instead
during scarcity.
